feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 9:56PM CST until November 29 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow off of Lake Winnipeg, Lake of the Woods, and Rainy Lake are expected in far northern St. Louis County. Overnight snow accumulation of 1 to 3 inches is forecast with total snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches expected by 6 AM Friday.
* WHERE...North St. Louis County. This includes the Tribal Lands of the Bois Forte Band, Nett Lake area. Recreation spots such as Voyageurs National Park. This also includes the Boundary Waters western area.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM CST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Lake effect snow will create reduced visibility slippery stretches on area roads.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM CST FRIDAY FOR FAR NORTHERN ST. LOUIS COUNTY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 9:56PM CST until November 30 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow is forecast over northern Bayfield County. Total snow accumulation of 2 to 7 inches.
* WHERE...Bayfield County. This includes the Tribal Lands of the Red Cliff Band. Recreation spots such as the Apostle Islands National Lakeshore.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM CST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday morning and evening commutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM CST SATURDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 9:56PM CST until November 30 at 6:00AM CST by NWS Duluth MN
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Lake effect snow showers. Additional snow accumulations between 1 and 3 inches except between 2 and 9 inches for northern Iron County.
* WHERE...Iron County. This includes the Tribal Lands of the northwestern area of the Lac du Flambeau Band. The greatest snow accumulation will be over northern Iron County. This also includes the communities of Upson, Iron Belt, Montreal, Gile, and Hurley and the following highways US-2, US-51, WI-169, WI-77, and WI-122.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM CST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday morning and evening commutes.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 AM CST SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 10:54PM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
At 1052 PM EST, radar indicated an intense lake effect snow band along a line extending from near Mentor to 6 miles south of Geneva, moving east at 15 mph. Travel conditions are becoming poor along parts of I-90 and route 2.
HAZARDS INCLUDE... Visibility rapidly dropping to less than a quarter of a mile... Snow rates of 1 inch per hour...
Locations impacted include... Painesville, Ashtabula, Willowick, Chardon, Fairport Harbor, Geneva-On-The-Lake, Euclid, Mentor, Willoughby, Eastlake, Geneva, Madison, North Kingsville, Perry, Timberlake, Lakeline, Wickliffe, Richmond Heights, Willoughby Hills, and Highland Heights.
Use extra caution if you must travel into or through this lake effect snow band. Rapid changes in visibility and potentially slick roads are likely to lead to accidents. Consider delaying travel until this snow band passes your location.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lake; Geauga; Ashtabula Inland; Ashtabula Lakeshore

cap:parameter.value: An intense lake effect snow band will affect northern Geauga... Lake and Ashtabula Counties Until 1230 AM EST.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued November 28 at 10:51PM EST until November 29 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
...STORM MOVING ON OUT BUT SLIPPERY CONDITIONS AND AREAS OF POWER OUTAGES TO CONTINUE OVERNIGHT...
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations up to two inches for a storm total of 6 to 12 inches.
* WHERE...Southern Somerset, Central Somerset, Northern Franklin, Northern Oxford, and Southern Franklin Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM EST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Snow will end overnight but roads will likely remain slippery into Friday morning with areas of power outages continuing.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northern Oxford; Northern Franklin; Central Somerset; Southern Franklin; Southern Somerset

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM EST FRIDAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 10:51PM EST until November 29 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
...STORM MOVING ON OUT BUT SLIPPERY CONDITIONS AND AREAS OF POWER OUTAGES TO CONTINUE OVERNIGHT...
* WHAT...Wet snow. Additional snow accumulations up to two inches for a storm total of 2 to 8 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Interior Waldo and Kennebec Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM EST Friday.
* IMPACTS...While the steadiest precipitation will end around or shortly after midnight roads may very well remain slippery overnight into Friday morning. Areas of power outages will continue overnight based on the heavy wet snow on branches and wires when combined with some wind.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM EST FRIDAY

entry.title: Freeze Warning issued November 28 at 9:39PM CST until November 30 at 8:00AM CST by NWS Jackson MS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Sub-freezing temperatures as low as 26 expected.
* WHERE...Portions of southeast Arkansas, northeast Louisiana, and north central Mississippi.
* WHEN...From 10 PM Friday to 8 AM CST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Frost and freeze conditions could kill sensitive vegetation and possibly damage unprotected outdoor plumbing.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 28 at 9:04PM CST until November 29 at 2:45AM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Calcasieu River Near Glenmora
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued late tonight at 245 AM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring.
* WHERE...Calcasieu River near Glenmora.
* WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, When the river is falling and the gauge reading is forecast to be near 12 feet, flooding of forested areas near the river will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM CST Thursday the stage was 12.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM CST Thursday was 12.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 7.1 feet Tuesday evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 8:59PM CST by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Light snow and flurries will continue this evening in central and north central Wisconsin. While snowfall will only be a dusting to half inch, some roads and sidewalks will become slick.
Please use caution traveling home from Thanksgiving festivities.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Oneida; Forest; Florence; Lincoln; Langlade; Marathon

cap:parameter.value: LIGHT SNOW WILL MAKE SOME ROADS AND SIDEWALKS SLICK

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 28 at 6:34PM PST until December 2 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Increased threat of sneaker waves from strong set behavior expected.
* WHERE...Coastal Del Norte, Northern Humboldt Coast, Southwestern Humboldt and Mendocino Coast Counties.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Monday afternoon. .
* IMPACTS...Large, unexpected waves can sweep across the beach without warning, sweeping people into the sea from rocks, jetties, and beaches. These sneaker waves can also move large objects such as logs, crushing anyone caught underneath.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...In addition, an upcoming new moon will bring higher than usual tides and strong tidal swings. This can increase the chances of getting getting caught in quickly rising tides with a building swell. Higher tides will also increase wave washover on rocks and jetties.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Del Norte; Northern Humboldt Coast; Southwestern Humboldt; Mendocino Coast

cap:parameter.value: BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY EVENING THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued November 28 at 9:17PM EST until December 1 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Gaylord MI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow. Total snow accumulations of 1 to 2 feet are expected through the holiday weekend for parts of the area. Locally higher amounts are possible, especially near Sault Ste. Marie.
* WHERE...Central Chippewa and Western Chippewa Counties.
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...High snowfall accumulations on roads and quick drops in visibility will lead to dangerous travel conditions at times through the holiday weekend. Gusty winds may lead to blowing snow, especially across exposed areas.

entry.title: High Surf Warning issued November 28 at 4:16PM HST until November 30 at 12:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF WARNING FOR NORTH AND WEST FACING SHORES OF NIIHAU KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI AND FOR NORTH FACING SHORES OF MAUI STARTING 6 AM HST FRIDAY...
* WHAT...Peak surf heights of 25 to 35 feet along north and west facing shores of Niihau and Kauai, for north facing shores of Oahu, Molokai and Maui. Peak surf heights of 15 to 20 feet along west facing shores of Oahu and Molokai.
* WHERE...North and west facing shores of Niihau, Kauai, Oahu, Molokai and for north facing shores of Maui.
* WHEN...From 6 AM Friday to noon HST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...High. Expect very strong breaking waves and powerful currents. Waves breaking in channel entrances may make navigating the channels dangerous.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Dangerously large surf expected along north and west facing coasts of Kauai Niihau Oahu Molokai and north shores of Maui.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Niihau; Kauai Southwest; Waianae Coast; Oahu North Shore; Maui Windward West; Kauai North; Koolau Windward; Molokai Windward; Molokai North; Molokai West; Windward Haleakala

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM FRIDAY TO NOON HST SATURDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 8:54PM EST by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary: Freshly falling snow may cover and hide dangerous icy patches on walkways and driveways that formed from falling temperatures. Use caution if traveling tonight, and expect snow covered roads and possible limited visibility from falling snow.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 6:50PM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
Areas of patchy fog will continue for the rest of the night along the Hi Line region. Fog can be dense at times, reducing visibility to less than a half mile.
Impacted areas include portions of the US Highway 2 including Shelby to Havre. For those driving, be prepared for sudden reductions in visibility, as well as icy roads.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Toole and Liberty; Hill County

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued November 28 at 8:47PM EST until November 29 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Caribou ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations between 4 and 6 inches for a storm total of 5 to 10 inches. Locally greater totals possible in an area from Piscataquis county to southeast Aroostook county.
* WHERE...Portions of Central Highlands, Far Eastern, Far Northern, North Woods, and Penobscot Valley Maine
* WHEN...Until 7 AM EST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Periods of locally heavy snowfall may lead to rapid snow accumulations. The weight of heavy, wet snow on tree limbs may down power lines and could cause sporadic power outages. Travel could be very difficult due to heavy snow creating low visibility, and wet roads freezing under new snow. These hazardous conditions will impact travel tonight through Friday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Aroostook; Northeast Aroostook; Northern Somerset; Northern Piscataquis; Northern Penobscot; Southeast Aroostook; Central Piscataquis; Central Penobscot; Southern Penobscot; Southern Piscataquis; Northern Washington

entry.title: Flood Warning issued November 28 at 8:02PM EST until November 29 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Tampa Bay Ruskin FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Withlacoochee At SR 200 Holder affecting Citrus County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Withlacoochee at SR 200 Holder.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, water approaches house foundations in Arrowhead subdivision.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 PM EST Thursday the stage was 8.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:45 PM EST Thursday was 8.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage just after midnight tonight and continue falling to 7.3 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.0 feet on 07/07/2003. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued November 28 at 3:07PM AKST until November 28 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SNOW POTENTIAL CONTINUES THROUGH THIS WEEKEND...
.Snow continues through tonight for the central Panhandle.
An additional round of heavy snow is forecasted for this weekend as warm moist air moves over the Panhandle starting Friday night. Expect snow to spread north through Saturday into Sunday, with the potential to see nearly a foot of snow along the Icy Strait Corridor and Hyder. The Central Panhandle will also likely receive a range of 3 to 6 inches of snow Saturday into Sunday.
Expect a transition to rainfall starting Saturday night for the southern Panhandle with rain expected along the Icy Strait corridor by Monday afternoon.
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Additional snow accumulations of 3 to 5 inches. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...City and Borough of Wrangell.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 9 PM AKST this evening. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Saturday afternoon through late Sunday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult and is discouraged.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM AKST THIS EVENING... ...WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE SUNDAY NIGHT

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 3:07PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
System details: Friday night an approaching system will feature deep moisture, driving 1 to 2 inches of snow through Saturday until warmer air at the surface arrives and a transition to all rain occurs overnight Saturday. As rainfall continues Sunday, 24 hour rainfall totals will be around 2 to 4 inches.
Timing: Snow starts near 10pm Friday night, continues to near 10pm Saturday evening.
24-hour snow totals: The current forecast takes a modest approach and falls in line with most model guidance means; highlighting a general 1 to 2 inches of wet and heavy snowfall in 24 hours. With that said, we will see locally higher amounts along elevated portions of the PoW road system. If QPF totals and snowfall rates surpass current forecast expectations, we could receive 3 to 5 inches.
Sleet/freezing rain potential: There also exists the potential for a few hours of sleet/freezing rain as snow transitions to rain Saturday night.
Confidence: High on timing. Low on 24 hour snow totals. Low on sleet/freezing rain.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Prince of Wales Island; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island

entry.title: Lake Effect Snow Warning issued November 28 at 6:07PM EST until November 30 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Cleveland OH
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy lake effect snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 6 and 21 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph, especially near the lakeshore.
* WHERE...Crawford, Northern Erie, and Southern Erie Counties.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 10 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...A multi-day lake effect snow event off Lake Erie will begin tonight and bring periodic heavy snow to the region. These heavy lake effect snow bands will bring occasional 1 to 2 inch per hour snowfall rates and poor visibility, as low as one quarter of a mile, which will make travel difficult to impossible, especially along Interstates 90, 86, and 79. The hazardous conditions will impact the Friday morning and evening commutes and any post-holiday travel.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Lower snow amounts are expected towards the southern part of Crawford County. Winds will shift to the southwest on Saturday and push heavy snow away from the region for a period. Lake effect snow is likely to return across the area on Sunday into early next week and bring additional snowfall. Additional winter weather headlines may be needed to address this next round of snow.

cap:parameter.value: LAKE EFFECT SNOW WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO 10 AM EST SATURDAY

* WHERE...Cuyahoga County.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to 10 AM EST Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Periodic, heavy lake effect snow bands will bring occasional one inch per hour snowfall rates and poor visibility, as low as one quarter of a mile, which will make travel difficult. Plan for slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the Friday morning and evening commutes and any post-holiday travel.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Greatest snowfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches are expected in the far northeast part of the county, including Euclid, Richmond Heights, Highland Heights, Mayfield, Gates Mills, and other neighboring communities.

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued November 28 at 2:16PM PST until December 1 at 1:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...A moderate risk of sneaker waves is expected.
* WHERE...All beaches and shorelines of Douglas, Coos, and Curry counties.
* WHEN...From Saturday evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Sneaker waves can run up significantly farther on beaches than normal, including over rocks and jetties. These waves can suddenly knock people off of their feet and quickly pull them into the cold ocean waters, resulting in serious injury or death. Waves may also lift driftwood logs, trapping anyone caught underneath.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Oregon Coast; Curry County Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued November 28 at 4:04PM CST by NWS Grand Forks ND
entry.summary: Lake effect snow will affect areas along the southeastern shores of Lake of the Woods toward Baudette and Koochiching County border this evening and overnight. Snow will fall in relatively narrow bands, quickly reducing visibility at times. Most likely snowfall accumulation will range from 2 to 4 inches through tonight, but could be locally higher within narrow bands. If traveling, be prepared for rapidly changing road conditions and visibilities. Travel could be difficult. Reduce your speed, turn on your headlights. Don't slam on brakes!

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued November 27 at 3:17PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
SABCO
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...A SPECIAL AVALANCHE ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 4:30 PM WEDNESDAY UNTIL 4:30 PM SUNDAY...
*WHAT...Avalanche conditions are more dangerous than weve experienced this season. *WHERE...All mountainous areas in Colorado *WHEN... From 4:30 PM Wednesday until 4:30 PM Sunday. *IMPACTS... Backcountry travelers can easily trigger dangerous avalanches large enough to injure or kill a human. *PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Avoid traveling on and under slopes with a slope angle steeper than about 30 degrees. You can trigger avalanches from a distance or from below. We will update the avalanche forecast each afternoon with more detailed information on local areas. Check it at www.colorado.gov/avalanche.
Davis
entry.cap:areaDesc: Elkhead and Park Mountains; Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains; Flat Tops; Northwestern San Juan Mountains; Southwest San Juan Mountains; West Jackson and West Grand Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and East Jackson/Larimer/North and Northeast Grand/Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; Larimer and Boulder Counties Between 6000 and 9000 Feet; Eastern Sawatch Mountains above 11000 Ft; Western Chaffee County Between 9000 and 11000 Ft; Eastern San Juan Mountains Above 10000 Ft
